item.title: Implicit midpoint method
item.description: Notations Let be \(\mathbf{q}\) be a field function of time \(t\) and \(\mathbf{\dot q}, \mathbf{\ddot q}\) be its first and second derivatives with respect to time \[ \left\{\begin{aligned} \mathbf{q} &= \mathbf{q}(t)\\ \mathbf{\dot q} &= \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathbf{q}}{\mathrm{d} t}\\ \mathbf{\ddot q} &= \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathbf{\dot q}}{\mathrm{d} t}\\ \end{aligned}\right. \] In order to make the description of the time integration algorithms less abstract, one can think of \(\mathbf{q},\mathbf{\dot q},\mathbf{\ddot q}\) as position, velocity and acceleration.
